messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for December 21, 2016 - December 27, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-12-28T20:38:51Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-12-21T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-12-27T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20161228-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.     

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period.  Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-12-21T15:00Z to 2016-12-21T18:00Z. This moderate elevation in geomagnetic activity was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2016-12-21 (see notifications 20161221-AL-001 and 20161221-AL-002).  The maximum value of solar wind speed reached >700 km/s on 2016-12-23.  

There were two coronal hole high speed streams detected by STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments on 2016-12-21 and 2016-12-26, respectively.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-12-22T14:45Z and had remained elevated (crossing the threshold several times) for the entire reporting period.  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above detected by DSCOVR at L1 (see notifications 20161222-AL-001, 20161222-AL-002, 20161224-AL-001, and 20161226-AL-001).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated electron fluxes on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-12-28T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-01-03T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be very low for the upcoming period.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.   Geomagnetic activity could increase due to the arrival of a coronal hole (currently located near the center of the solar disk) high speed stream at around 2016-12-31.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-12-28T17:34:36Z
## Message ID: 20161228-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-12-22T14:45Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by  high speed stream starting at 2016-12-21T03:37Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-12-22T14:45:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for December 14, 2016 - December 20, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-12-21T19:27:04Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-12-14T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-12-20T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20161221-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

Around 2016-12-20, a coronal hole high speed stream was detected by STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments.  Solar wind speeds reached values close to 600 km/s.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week. 

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-12-15T07:12Z     ~506            C               -90/3                 14                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-12-21T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-12-27T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  The active regions on the solar surface appear to have low magnetic complexity.  There is an active region showing on the northeast limb at STEREO A EUVI that could produce some flares and coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2016-12-21.  Currently, the Kp index has reached moderate values of Kp=6 for the synoptic period of 2016-12-21T15:00Z to 2016-12-21T18:00Z. 

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-12-21T18:50:16Z
## Message ID: 20161221-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-12-21T15:00Z to 2016-12-21T18:00Z. 

The storm is caused by high speed stream starting at 2016-12-21T03:37Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-12-21T15:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes: 




NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for December 07, 2016 - December 13, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-12-15T16:14:56Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-12-07T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-12-13T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20161215-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.   The maximum value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2016-12-09T18:00Z-24:00Z.  This slight elevation in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2016-12-07.  Solar wind speed reached values greater than 700 km/s on 2016-12-09.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-12-10T15:00Z. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above.  The fluxes remained elevated for a couple of days.  (See notifications 20161210-AL-001, 20161210-AL-002 and 20161212-AL-001).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevation on the energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above. 


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-12-12T06:54Z     ~599            C               135/23                27                          STEREO A, SOHO                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-12-14T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-12-20T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the next upcoming period.   Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are some small coronal holes present on the Earth's facing side that could cause some minor disturbances.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-12-12T13:33:38Z
## Message ID: 20161212-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux continues to be above and around 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-12-10T15:00Z and crossing again at 2016-12-12T13:10T. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2016-12-07T18:40Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-12-10T15:00:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for November 30, 2016 - December 06, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-12-08T01:30:59Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-11-30T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-12-06T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20161208-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period. 

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2016-12-04.  The solar wind speed reached values higher than 600 km/s.   

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was elevated at the beginning of the reporting period crossing the threshold of 10^5 pfu around 2016-11-30T16:30Z.  This activity was associated with the ongoing effects of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2016-11-24.  Levels started declining after this day and remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate (at/near GEO orbit) this week due to the radiation belt electron flux enhancement mentioned above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:

2016-12-04T14:24Z     ~519            C                71/21                13                          SOHO                              
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-12-07T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-12-13T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to remain low to moderate for the next reporting period.  The geomagnetic activity is expected to increase at the beginning of the next reporting period due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream. The coronating interactive region has already been detected on 2016-12-07 by DSCOVR at L1.  Solar wind speed values higher than 700 km/s are expected.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for November 23, 2016 - November 29, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-12-01T04:21:43Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-11-23T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-11-29T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20161201-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period with 2 M-class flares (see list below).     

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period.  Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-11-25T03:00Z to 2016-11-25T06:00Z. This moderate geomagnetic storm was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2016-11-24 (see notifications 20161125-AL-001 and 20161125-AL-003).  

Around 2016-11-27 there was also a coronal hole high speed stream arrival detected at STEREO A.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-11-25T13:35Z, and remained elevated for the rest of the reporting period.  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20161125-AL-002, 20161125-AL-004, 20161127-AL-001, 20161129-AL-001). 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due the energetic electron fluxes in the outer radiation belt described above.

Flares (M-class and above)

2016-11-29  17:19:00  17:26:00  17:23:00   M1.0   S08E54 ( 12615 ) 
2016-11-29  23:29:00  23:40:00  23:38:00   M1.2   S08E54 ( 12615 ) 


CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-11-30T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-12-06T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the recent activity by active region 12615 currently located around S07E35.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to remain low for the upcoming week.  There is a possible small geomagnetic enhancement around 2016-12-04 due to a small coronal hole high speed stream.
